original_title: 3D Printed Aerospike was Designed by AI
original_content:
Were still in the early days of generatively-designed objects, but when combined with the capabilities of 3D printing, were already seeing some interesting results. One example is this new copper aerospike engine. [via Fabbaloo]
A collaboration between startups Hyperganic (generative AI CAD) and AMCM (additive manufacturing), this 800 mm long aerospike engine may be the most complicated 3D print yet. It continues the exciting work being done with 3D printing for aerospace applications. The complicated geometries of rocket nozzles of any type let additive manufacturing really shine, so the combination of generative algorithms and 3D printed nozzles could result in some big leaps in coming years.
Aerospikes are interesting as their geometry isnt pressure dependent like more typical bell-shaped rocket nozzles meaning you only need one engine for your entire flight profile instead of the traditional switching mid-flight. A linear aerospike engine was one of the main selling points for the cancelled VentureStar Space Shuttle replacement.
This isnt the only generative design headed to space, and weve covered a few projects if youre interested in building your own 3D printed rocket nozzles or aerospike engines. Just make sure you get clearance from your local aviation regulator before your project goes to space!
title: 3DプリンティングとAIを活用した新しい宇宙航空エンジンの誕生
body: 未来には、3Dプリンティングの能力と組み合わせた生成設計オブジェクトが可能になる。HyperganicとAMCMのスタートアップが協業し、長さ800 mmの銅製のエアロスパイクエンジンを開発した。このエンジンは、航空宇宙分野の3D印刷技術による複雑なジオメトリを活用し、今後さらに発展が期待されています。銅製エアロスパイクエンジンは、線形エアロスパイクエンジンを採用した VentureStar スペースシャトルの代替案でも使用されていました。
